* You will be able to maintain >6 feet distance from people you do not live with.

droplets.description:
* Some instruments may be riskier than others. 
* Blowing into an instrument or singing produces a very high amount of droplets. 
* These droplets and particles can infect others with COVID-19. 
* Consider taking lessons virtually, and practicing in the privacy of your home away from others.

masking.description:
* Depending on the instrument, masks are worn inconsistently or by few individuals even during face to face encounters.
* However, you should still wear a mask before and after your lesson.
* You should feel comfortable keeping your mask on even if others remove theirs. 
* Make sure that your mask covers your nose and mouth.

exposureTime.description:
* You have extended periods of face to face contact.
* Music lessons usually last at least 1 hour at a time, resulting in more than 15 minutes of face-to-face contact
* Depending on the lesson, see if virtual options are available in order to have a full lesson.

ventilation.description:
* Indoor residential spaces have poor ventilation which allows viral particles to build up over time and increase the risk of contracting COVID-19
* Consider going outside to reduce this risk factor.
* If you are unable to go outside, open windows and doors, minimize time indoors with others from outside your household, maintain a safe distance and wear face coverings.
* Consider high quality, virus-removing air filters, like MERV 13 or HEPA filters with enough airflow for the size of your space.

* However, when outdoors some folks may choose to remove their masks when not engaged in direct face-to-face contact. 
* As the masking rate declines, the risk of transmission increases.
* Try to encourage others to wear a mask that covers their nose and mouth, and feel comfortable keeping yours on even if others take theirs off.

crowding.description:
* Playing with friends is an important way for kids to build social skills. 
* Yet, it is likely they will be unable to maintain >6 feet distance from people who are not in their household. 
* Consider an outdoor playdate with activities that can be done from a safer distance, like coloring with chalk on the sidewalk or having a snowball fight.

droplets.description:
* Children breathing heavily, laughing, and shouting can produce many droplets which can be breathed in or land in other kids' eyes, mouths, and noses.
* These droplets can also land on play area surfaces and spread when children touch their eyes, nose or mouth.
* During play and conversation, both you and your children can prevent exposure to COVID-19 by wearing masks to interrupt the flight of droplets.
* Using hand sanitizer frequently and teaching your children not to touch their face can prevent them from picking up any stray droplets.

masking.description:
* It might be harder for children to consistently keep their masks on.

crowding.description:
* Playing sports is an important way to maintain physical health and friendships. 
* In many sports, teams get very close together before, during, and after games.
* Try to be concious of standing too close on the sidelines, and consider leaving right after the game is over.

droplets.description:
* Players may shout instructions and breathe heavily among other droplet-producing behaviors.
* These can produce droplets that carry COVID-19 and expose players to COVID-19

masking.description:
* Masking in public spaces is required in many states but not all.
* However, during strenuous exercise some people may wear their mask inconsistently or not at all. 
* You should feel comfortable keeping your mask on even if others remove theirs. 
* Make sure that your mask covers your nose and mouth.

exposureTime.description:
* Many sports involve direct face-to-face contact between players during the course of a game or before and after a game.
* Those moments are often short but can happen many times during a game.
* These moments can quickly add up to more than 15 minutes total, which increases your risk of transmitting or getting COVID-19.

ventilation.description:
* Sports played outside are better than those played in even a well-ventilated indoor space.
* Outside, air currents, sunlight, humidity, and other factors help to dissipate droplets produced by others and reduce the infectiousness of those droplets.
* Try to pay attention to the other risk factors as well.

crowding.description:
* Keeping medical appointments is important for maintaining overall health!
* However, the location may be crowded depending on the size of the office and time of day. 
* Try to leave an empty seat or space between yourself and others in the waiting room, and schedule during less busy times.

droplets.description:
* Talking creates a moderate amount of droplets.  
* Wear a mask while face-to-face with others, and keep talking to a minimum in the waiting room.

masking.description:
* Masking in public spaces is required in many states but not all.
* You should feel comfortable keeping your mask on even if others remove theirs. 
* Make sure that your mask covers your nose and mouth.

exposureTime.description:
* Going to an eye exam means you will have extended face-to-face contact with another person.
* In general, spending 15 minutes or more total face-to-face time significantly increases your risk of getting or giving COVID-19. 
* We consider this a high risk factor as a result.

ventilation.description:
* Indoor commercial spaces have better ventilation which prevents viral particles that could get you sick from building up over time. 
* Contact your doctor's office to see if they have installed high quality, virus-removing air filters, like MERV 13 or HEPA filters with enough airflow for the size of your space.
* Consider asking your doctor to open windows and doors, and everyone should wear face coverings.

crowding.description:
* Giving gifts is a major part of celebrating the holidays. 
* However, going to an event with lots of family or friends means you will not be able to consistently maintain 6 feet of distance. 
* Consider taking your holiday gift exchange online this year, and shipping your gifts to family and friends. 
* Or, commit to a much smaller gathering with just immediate family members if you can take additional precautions.

droplets.description:
* Holiday gatherings are a celebratory time, so you and those around you are likely talking, laughing, and maybe even singing! 
* This means there are a high amount of droplets and particles being produced, which can spread COVID-19. 
* Ask everyone to wear masks for the duration of the event, or move the event online to minimize or stop the spread of infectious particles.

masking.description:
* Few people at an indoor party will likely keep their masks on. 
* Try to move the party outdoors and make it a requirement that everyone masks. 
* You should feel comfortable keeping your mask on even if others remove theirs. 
* Make sure that your mask covers your nose and mouth.

exposureTime.description:
* Spending time indoors with friends or family to exchange gifts means you will have direct face-to-face exposure with others. 
* When you have more than 15 minutes total contact with others, it can increase your risk of getting or giving COVID-19. 
* Consider doing a progressive gift exchange, where you caravan from house to house and spend only a few minutes passing out gifts.

ventilation.description:
* Although this can happen both indoors and outdoors, the activity is short enough that risk of exposure due to ventilation is low.
* Consider going outside to reduce this risk factor.
* If you are unable to go outside, open windows and doors, minimize time indoors with others from outside your household, maintain a safe distance and wear face coverings.

crowding.description:
* Taking photos with Santa is a cherished holiday tradition.
* Waiting in lines can get crowded when many familes are visiting at the same time.
* Try to visit at times when it is less crowded, or find a location that has appointment times to take your photos.

droplets.description:
* Talking normally produces some droplets.
* You and your family can prevent exposure to COVID-19 by wearing masks to interrupt the flight of droplets.

masking.description:

* However, some folks may choose to remove their masks when not engaged in direct face-to-face contact. 
* As the masking rate declines, the risk of transmission increases.
* Try to encourage others to wear a mask that covers their nose and mouth, and feel comfortable keeping yours on even if others take theirs off even in photos.

exposureTime.description:

* You can keep encounters to less than 5 minutes of direct exposure.
* Try not to be indoors for more than 15 minutes.

* In most cases, being outside is better than even a well-ventilated indoor space.

* Making an alter is an important way to honor and remember loved ones. 
* If you do this activity with only those you live with, you will not pass near others for the duration of the activity. 
* If you do this activity with people outside your household, the risk is higher.
* Take the time to remind folks to stay 6+ ft apart, and take turns to give everyone enough space.

droplets.description:
* Droplets and particles can be produced from normal talking or heavy breathing.
* But, assuming that you are doing this activity with only people you live with, you will likely not encounter droplets or particles produced by others. 
* Try to keep conversations with people outside your household to a minimum.

masking.description:
* Masking may not be necessary with people you live with, unless someone is feeling ill.
* Informal gatherings might not have a masking requirement, and many people might feel comfortable taking off their mask. 
* Try to set an expectation that everyone stays masked if people from outside your household will be joining you. 
* You should feel comfortable keeping your mask on even if others remove theirs.

exposureTime.description:
* If you make alters with only those you live with, you will have passing contact with other people. 
* Remember to minimize time spent with extended family you do not live with to protect them and yourself.
* This means keeping encounters to less than 15 minutes of direct face-to-face exposure.

ventilation.description:
* If you're doing this activity indoors, particles might build up to infectious levels, and droplets can travel without being stopped by strong airflow. 
* If you are able, move this activity outside.
* Open windows and doors and turn on fans to get the air moving. 
* If you're able to, invest in standalone HEPA air filters and replace the filters in your HVAC system with MERV 13 or above.

indoor-party.name: go to an indoor party
indoor-party.searchName: go to an indoor party or celebration

crowding.description:
* It's important to stay connected with friends and family. And there are still things to celebrate.
* But at an indoor party, you could be near people you do not live with for the duration of activity.
* Try an outdoor or virtual party instead.
* If you are unable to, try to find a large space where people can spread out and make sure to space out when people arrive and leave the room.

droplets.description:
* It's a party! You and those around you might be shouting, singing, or laughing.
* That means that you are producing high amounts of droplets and particles.
* Try to reduce droplet production by keeping shouting and sing-a-longs at a minimum.
* Going outside is better, but going virtual might be a good option that lets you go all out.

masking.description:
* Few people at an indoor party with friends and family will likely keep their masks on.
* Try to move the party outdoors and insist that everyone masks.
* You should feel comfortable keeping your mask on even if others remove theirs.
* Make sure that your mask covers your nose and mouth.

exposureTime.description:
* If you go to an indoor party, you'll likely have extended periods of face-to-face contact.
* You will also be indoors for more than 1 hour
* Try to reduce your face-to-face contact and move outside or online if possible

ventilation.description:
* You're indoors! That means that the concentration of viral particles might build up to infectious levels, and droplets can travel without being interrupted by strong airflow.
* Open windows and doors and turn on fans to get the air moving. 
* If you're able to, invest in standalone HEPA air filters and replace the filters in your HVAC system with MERV 13 or above.

outdoor-party.name: go to an outdoor party
outdoor-party.searchName: go to an outdoor party or celebration

crowding.description:
* It's important to stay connected with friends and family.
* At the party, you may occassionally pass near people you do not live with.
* Try to keep gatherings smaller or consider moving them online. 
* Take the time to remind folks to stay 6+ ft apart before and during the gathering.

droplets.description:
* It's a party! You and those around you might be shouting, singing, or laughing.
* That means that you are producing high amounts of droplets and particles.
* Try to reduce droplet production by keeping shouting and sing-a-longs at a minimum.
* Going virtual might be a good option that lets you go all out.

masking.description:
* Eating and drinking during the party will cause many people to take their masks off.
* That means masks are worn inconsistently or by few individuals even during face-to-face encounters.
* Not serving food and drinks might mean that less people take off their masks or keep them off for shorter periods of time.
* Designating a socially distant eating and drink area where people shouldn't chat might help to reduce the number of people who take off their masks.

exposureTime.description:
* At the party, you will likely have extended periods (15+ minutes) of face-to-face contact with people outside your household.
* Smaller groups can help reduce face-to-face exposure. People will be more spread out but will still feel involved and engaged.

ventilation.description:
* You're outdoors! That means that the concentration of viral particles won't build up to infectious levels, and droplets get blown to the ground before they reach others.
* Try to pay attention to the other risk factors as well.

outdoor-haunted-forest.name: go to an outdoor haunted forest
outdoor-haunted-forest.searchName: go to an outdoor haunted forest

crowding.description:
* Haunted forests are a fun part of Halloween
* At the haunted forests, you may occassionally come closer than 6 feet distance from other visitors.
* Try to visit haunted forests that have reservations, one-way signage, and visitor caps to reduce crowding.
* Try to keep moving so visitors in other groups don't run into you.

droplets.description:
* Haunted forests are scary and dark! You and those around you might be shouting, screaming, or laughing.
* That means that you are producing high amounts of droplets and particles.
* Try to reduce droplet production by stifling those screams.
* Look away from the scary thing or those around you as you scream to point droplets away from others.

masking.description:
* Many haunted forests require masking, but as people run around they may remove their mask while not face-to-face with someone else.
* Try to go to a haunted forest that requires masking.
* You should feel comfortable keeping your mask on even if others remove theirs.
* Make sure that your mask covers your nose and mouth.

exposureTime.description:
* If you go to the haunted forest with only those you live with, you will have passing contact with other people.
* You should be able to keep encounters to less than <5 minutes of direct exposure 
* Try to keep conversations with people outside your household short.

ventilation.description:
* You're outdoors! That means that the concentration of viral particles won't build up to infectious levels, and droplets get blown to the ground before they reach others.
* Try to pay attention to the other risk factors as well.

outdoor-movie-night.name: go to an outdoor movie night
outdoor-movie-night.searchName: go to an outdoor movie night

crowding.description:
* Halloween movies are a fun tradition.
* At an outdoor movie night, you are able to maintain 6+ ft distance from people you do not live with at all times.
* Try to visit to find a spot to sit 6+ ft from others.
* Don't be afraid to ask for more space or move if you need to.

droplets.description:
* Movies are quiet affairs, but you and those around you might talk a bit.
* That means that you are producing some droplets and particles.
* Try to keep conversations with people outside your household at a minimum.
* Don't heckle the movie. You'll disrupt the movie and produce droplets.

masking.description:
* Informal gatherings might not have a masking requirement, and many people might feel comfortable taking off their mask outside.
* Try to go to or organize an outdoor movie that requires masking.
* You should feel comfortable keeping your mask on even if others remove theirs.
* Make sure that your mask covers your nose and mouth.

exposureTime.description:

* You should be able to keep encounters to less than <5 minutes of direct exposure

visit-grave-loved.searchName: visiting and decorating graves of loved ones

crowding.description:
* Visiting the graves of loved ones is important and meaningful.
* At the graveyard, you are likely able to maintain 6+ from people you do not live with. 
* Try to visit the grave with only those you live with.
* Try to take turns tending to the grave so everyone can maintain 6+ ft of space.

droplets.description:
* You may pray or talk to your loved one.
* Talking produces more droplets and particles than normal breathing.  
* Try to keep your voice quiet or say your prayers silently.

masking.description:
* Informal gatherings might not have a masking requirement, and many people might feel comfortable taking off their mask outside.
* Try to set an expectation that everyone stays masked if people from outside your household will be joining you.

outdoor-religious-service.name: going to an outdoor religious service
outdoor-religious-service.searchName: going to an outdoor religious service

crowding.description:
* A religious service connects us to our faith and community.
* But it might get crowded during the holidays, and you may occassionally pass near others you do not live with.
* Try to find a place to sit 6+ ft from others in all directions.
* Attend the service virtually if possible.

droplets.description:
* Most religious services involve chanting, singing, and prayers as well as talking to other people.
* That means that you and those around you are producing high amounts of droplets and particles
* Try to keep your voice quiet, say your prayers silently, and skip chanting and singing.
* Going virtual might be a good option if you want to sing and do other droplet-producing activities.

masking.description:
* Masking at religious gatherings is required in many states but not all.
* In states that require masking, almost everyone is likely masked. 
* As the masking rate declines, the risk of transmission increases.
* Try to encourage others to mask and feel comfortable keeping yours on.

exposureTime.description:
* At a service, you'll likely see friends that you want to catch up with.
* This will result in some face-to-face contact
* Try to keep encounters shorter, but they will likely lead to 5 to 15 minutes of direct face-to-face exposure.

ventilation.description:
* You're outdoors! That means that the concentration of viral particles won't build up to infectious levels, and droplets get blown to the ground before they reach others.
* Try to pay attention to the other risk factors as well.

droplets.description:

* Many visitors will also be talking to one another. These all produce droplets and particles.
* Try to use noisemakers, pots, and pans instead of shouting

masking.description:

1.longDescription:
* You can continue to do this activity.
* The frequency and nature of the activity puts you at low risk for contracting or transmitting COVID-19.
* You may still want to take extra precautions for prevent infection, including covering your face with a cloth or non-medical mask.

riskLevel1.longDescription:
* You can continue to do this activity.
* The frequency and nature of the activity puts you at low risk for contracting or transmitting COVID-19.
* You may still want to take extra precautions for prevent infection, including covering your face with a cloth or non-medical mask.

riskLevel2.longDescription:
* You can continue to do this activity but you should consider ways to do this activity less or during less risky times.
* The frequency and nature of the activity puts you at some risk for contracting or transmitting COVID-19.
* Make sure to take extra precautions for prevent infection, like frequently washing your hands (with soap) for at least 20 seconds, remaining 6 feet from another person, and covering your face with a cloth or non-medical mask.

riskLevel3.longDescription:
* You should consider stopping this activity.
* If you are unable to stop, you should consider ways to do this activity less or during less risky times.
* The frequency and nature of the activity puts you at more risk for contracting or transmitting COVID-19.
* Extra precautions to preventing infection are not enough, like frequently washing your hands (with soap) for at least 20 seconds and remaining 6 feet from another person, and covering your face with a cloth or non-medical mask.

riskLevel4.longDescription:
* You should stop this activity.
* If you are unable to stop, you should consider ways to do this activity less or during less risky times and take precautions.
* The frequency and nature of the activity puts you at high risk for contracting or transmitting COVID-19. 
* You may be endangering others and efforts to control the outbreak. 
* Extra precautions to preventing infection are not enough, like frequently washing your hands (with soap) for at least 20 seconds and remaining 6 feet from another person, covering your face with a cloth or non-medical mask.

riskLevel5.longDescription:
* Stop this activity immediately. 
* If you are unable to stop, you should consider ways to do this activity less or during less risky times and take precautions.
* The frequency and nature of the activity is endangering yourself and efforts to control the COVID-19 outbreak, regardless of extra precautions to preventing infection, like frequently washing your hands (with soap) for at least 20 seconds, remaining 6 feet from another person, and covering your face with a cloth or non-medical mask.

COVIDpositive.longDescription:
The CDC recommends the following:

* When you need medical care, call ahead to the doctor or medical facility to alert them that you have COVID-19 so they can prepare to care for you and protect others at the facility.
* Outside of getting medical care, you should isolate yourself to your home. Do not go to work, school, place of worship or other public areas. Avoid using public transportation, ride-sharing or taxis.

Learn more: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html
COVIDpositive.name: COVIDpositive
COVIDpositive.shortDescription: You or someone in your household has tested positive for COVID-19 (coronavirus) in the last 14 days.

age.description: You are in the 50+ age bracket
age.longDescription:
Older adults may be at higher risk for more serious complications from COVID-19.

The CDC recommends taking the following precautions:
* Stay home if possible.
* Wash your hands often.
* Avoid close contact (6 feet, which is about two arm lengths) with people who are sick.
* Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces.
* Avoid all cruise travel and non-essential air travel.
* Call your healthcare professional if you have concerns about COVID-19 and your underlying condition or if you are sick.
* For more information on steps you can take to protect yourself, see CDCs How to Protect Yourself

Learn more: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/specific-groups/high-risk-complications/older-adults.html

age.shortDescription: Your age puts you at a higher risk for COVID-19

comorbidity.description: You have underlying chronic medical conditions
comorbidity.longDescription:

The CDC recommends taking the following precautions:
* Stay home if possible.
* Wash your hands often.
* Avoid close contact (6 feet, which is about two arm lengths) with people who are sick.
* Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces.
* Avoid all cruise travel and non-essential air travel.
* Call your healthcare professional if you have concerns about COVID-19 and your underlying condition or if you are sick.
* For more information on steps you can take to protect yourself, see <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prepare/prevention.html">CDCs How to Protect Yourself<a>

Learn more: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/underlying-conditions.html

* Call your healthcare professional if you have concerns about COVID-19 and your underlying condition or if you are sick.

pregnant.longDescription:
The CDC recommends that pregnant women should do the same things as the general public to avoid infection. You can help stop the spread of COVID-19 by taking these actions:
 
* Cover your cough (using your elbow is a good technique)
* Avoid people who are sick
* Clean your hands often using soap and water or alcohol-based hand sanitizer
 
Learn more: https://www.who.int/news-room/q-a-detail/q-a-on-covid-19-pregnancy-childbirth-and-breastfeeding
Learn more: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prepare/pregnancy-breastfeeding.html
pregnant.name: pregnant
pregnant.shortDescription: Pregnant women experience changes in their bodies that may increase their risk of some infections.

smoking.longDescription:
Smokers or individuals with a history of smoking/vaping may be at higher risk for more serious complications from COVID-19.
 
If you are able to avoid smoking for the time being, you may want to consider smoking/vaping alternatives.
 
If you are unable to avoid smoking/vaping for the time being, you may want to:
* Avoid sharing smoking/vaping products such as water pipes or cigarettes.
* Wash your hands thoroughly before smoking/vaping
 
Learn more: https://www.who.int/news-room/q-a-detail/q-a-on-smoking-and-covid-19
Learn more: https://www.drugabuse.gov/about-nida/noras-blog/2020/03/covid-19-potential-implications-individuals-substance-use-disorders
Learn more: https://tobacco.ucsf.edu/reduce-your-risk-serious-lung-disease-caused-corona-virus-quitting-smoking-and-vaping l

Learn more: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prepare/pregnancy-breastfeeding.html

pregnant.shortDescription: Pregnant women experience changes in their bodies that may increase their risk of some infections.

smoking.longDescription:
Smokers or individuals with a history of smoking/vaping may be at higher risk for more serious complications from COVID-19.
 
If you are able to avoid smoking for the time being, you may want to consider smoking/vaping alternatives.
 
If you are unable to avoid smoking/vaping for the time being, you may want to:
* Avoid sharing smoking/vaping products such as water pipes or cigarettes.
* Wash your hands thoroughly before smoking/vaping
 
Learn more: https://www.who.int/news-room/q-a-detail/q-a-on-smoking-and-covid-19
Learn more: https://www.drugabuse.gov/about-nida/noras-blog/2020/03/covid-19-potential-implications-individuals-substance-use-disorders
Learn more: https://tobacco.ucsf.edu/reduce-your-risk-serious-lung-disease-caused-corona-virus-quitting-smoking-and-vaping l
